titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p:
1. Mr: Jewett called upon me this morning, and gave me the first information of the Death of the Queen of Prussia— That all the Prussian Ports were interdicted to all American vessels, and that the French, Austrian and Westphalian Ministers had left Berlin— Mr: Jewett also asked my opinion with regard to the propriety of an American Citizen’s entering the service of Russia, intimating that he had such a disposition himself under the expectation that in case the war with Turkey should continue, there would be room for active service on the Black Sea, and if Peace should ensue, an opportunity to facilitate the commercial intercourse between the United States and that part of the world— I told him that so far as my own opinion went, I saw no impropriety in his purpose; and did not think much of the liberality of the principle, which would forbid every American Citizen from entering the Service of a foreign Sovereign in Amity with the United States— But I observed to him that this was not the prevailing opinion in America— If the newspaper accounts were to be credited a proposed
for an Amendment to the Constitution of the United States, had passed by the requisite majority of both Houses of Congress, at their last Session, by which if it should become part of the Constitution, an American Citizen would forfeit his rights and character as such, by the mere act of entering into a foreign Service— Even if this project should not be adopted by three fourths of the State Legislatures, its passage by two thirds of both Houses of Congress was an indication of the prevailing current of popular opinion in America— He asked me whether I knew that it was a regulation in this Country that an Officer coming from a Republican service to enter that of Russia, must take a grade lower than that he had before held— I had not heard of any such rule— He said he had been told there was one, introduced during the reign of the Empress Elizabeth— But he understood that an Officer who had been Aid de Camp to General Eaton, and as such ranked as Major, though he had only a Captain’s Commission, was admitted as a Major, into the Russian service— This to be sure would be a strong case, since Eaton himself never had any Commission Military, higher than a lieutenant, and was a General only of his own Creation. He added that he could not consent to enter this Service in a lower Station than that which he held in the service of the United States; where he was a Commander of a Sloop of War— It was impossible he should accept a lieutenant’s Commission, when he considered the general level of the Officers of that rank here.— Mr: Jewett made an excuse for not dining with us this day, and brought one from Mr: Barthe— Mr: Harris, and Mr: Roberts, with Messrs Osgood, Ashton and Plummer dined with us— Mr: Raimbert came in after dinner, and confirmed the Accounts from Prussia— I walked out on the Moscow road, and measured a Werst in walking— I found it 1366 paces going, and 1375 returning— I had estimated it at 1334— In the Evening I received from the Grand Master of the Ceremonies Narishkin, a notification of a Court mourning of six weeks, divided into two equal parts; for the Queen of Prussia—to commence to-morrow— Catherine Johnson was very unwell this day; and confined to her chamber.

2. Mr: Harris came and introduced to me, a Dr: Griffiths; a Gentleman born at Philadelphia, but who left America, at the age of seven years, which must have been about thirty-five years ago, since which he has not been in that Country— His father he says purchased an Estate in Wales— He himself has resided twelve years in India, and during the last five years has been at Vienna. He comes with letters of Recommendation from persons of high distinction at the Court of Austria, to the Empress Mother, and to the principal nobility here— His object is to enter the service of Russia, in the line of his profession; but he does not appear to consider his prospects as promising— Mr: Harris afterwards called a second time, and shewed me a Note from Count Romanzoff, with another forgery of an American Register, of the London fabrication— I wrote to Mr: Gray, and purchased at the Russian Bookstall Ricard’s Traité-General du Commerce, and Lipp’s Guide du Négociant; with some old English music, and Delille’s poem on the Imagination—

3. I had a visit this morning from Mr: Barthe; a Frenchman, who is a Citizen of the United States; lately arrived from America, and intending to return there soon. I wrote part of a letter to the Secretary of State. Dined at Baron de Blome’s at Kammenoi Ostroff; with a company of about thirty-five persons— All the Corps Diplomatique, of the French alliance were there— Madame de Vlodek, and her Sister Constance were the only Ladies— Colonel Donnat the aid de Camp of the late king of Holland, who is here as a traveller, and came lately from Sweden by the way of Tornea told me that he had seen Regnard’s Inscription, which was in a Church near the Lake of Tornea— But that Regnard and his companion were mistaken, in supposing themselves at the world’s end. They had mistaken the Lake of Tornea for the Sea— He himself had been two degrees farther North than Regnard, and General Skïoldebrand had been to the North Cape, which was five degrees further North— I asked Count St: Julien, about the new life of Prince Eugene, said to have been written by himself— He says he does not believe it genuine; but that it was written by a French Emigrant; with some passages which might have been from the hand of the Prince— After dinner I took a walk with Mr: Smith in Count Strogonoff’s Garden on the Island; where we saw the tomb of Homer, and several other remarkable works of art— I particularly noticed a Statue of Granit, of very imperfect workmanship which I took to be of Egyptian and very early sculpture— And a Marble Statue of the Art in its highest perfection— A man on one knee, sharpening a knife upon a Stone.
There are also before the House two Colossal Marble Statues, copies from Antiques; one of Hercules; and the other a Goddess with an oaken crown—perhaps Minerva— Count Strogonoff is the greatest friend and patron of the Arts, in this Country.— From the Petersburg Island, I walked by the way of Wasili-Ostroff home— The sky and temperature of the atmosphere, have already the appearance of Autumn.

4. Mr: Harris sent me this morning, from Mr: Borel two copies of his comparative tables of the Russian weights, measures, and Coins with those of other Countries; and one of his Book upon the functions of Consuls, with the Supplement— He afterwards brought me the copy of my observations upon Mr: Borel’s Manuscript, to which he was desirous that I should make a slight addition— He also brought a copy of the preface which Mr: Borel proposes prefixing to the work— I was all day at home, and took only my Evening walk.

5. I was all the morning at home— The Gentlemen all dined abroad— Immediately after dinner, I took a row-boat; and with Mrs: Adams and Catherine Johnson, my boy Charles and Martha we went from the Canal at the Corner of our Street into and up the River to Mr: Krehmer Country Seat—it is opposite the Convent of Noble young Ladies, above the Tauridan palace, and on the other side of the River— The distance is about five Miles; which in ascending the stream, rowing at the same time against the wind took us two hours— We found Mr: Krehmer and all his family were gone out; to a party at their neighbour Count Kotschubey’s; who is going away on Tuesday; and a play at their other neighbour Bezborodko’s— They soon came home however— Mr: Krehmer’s mother also was there; and Mr: and Mrs: Bailey, their brother and Sister in Law— After passing about an hour there, we returned in the boat, and landed at the Corner of the Winter Palace, whence we walked home— We came down in about half an hour; muffled in Surtouts and wadded pelisses— I read Massillon’s funeral Oration upon Louis the Dauphin, Son of Louis 14— History represents this prince, as brave; benevolent, indolent and voluptuous— The bishop of Clermont makes him a model of perfection;—though indeed he does give a transient glance at the irregularities of his early life— There is in this Discourse another bitter invective, against William 3. and a character of him, drawn in a few lines, and with great spirit— Piteous lamentations at the reverse of France’s Fortune’s, which are astonishing to the Bishop considering the piety of Louis le Grand; who had taken away the high places— That is, who had revoked the Edict of Nantes— So that in Massillon’s opinion the persecution of Protestants, gave Louis Le Grand, a fair claim to the interposition of the Almighty; that he might enjoy perpetual victory over Protestants. His only conclusion is that the Sins of the Nation of have more than counterbalanced the merits of the king; and that to punish them, he afflicts the man after his own heart (Louis 14) with disasters— So much for preaching politicks— Yet Massillon constantly preaches Christian humility—the forgiveness of injuries and conflict with the world— There is even an excellent passage in this spirit, relating to the death of the Emperor, then at War with France— There are also fine Characters of the Duke de Montausier and of Bossuet, the Instructors and Governor’s of the Dauphin’s Youth. Beauvilliers and Fenelon, are only mentioned with honour.— This is the anniversary of the day when we sailed from Charlestown, for St: Petersburg— The year has flown swiftly away— And as of all former years, I have not improved it as I ought. The opportunity to do essential good, has not yet occurr’d— Let me yet implore the father of Spirits; for the occasion—for the resolution, perseverance and skill to improve it; and for the success which he alone can give in reward of good intents, which he alone can inspire.

6. I received this morning from Archangel a letter from Mr: William Gray, at Boston, with a file of Newspapers to the last of April— Mr: Harris called here, and I gave him again the observations upon Mr: Borel’s Manuscript, with a small addition at his request— He afterwards sent me a Providence paper of 25 May— As usual on the receipt of American Papers, I could not leave them, untill I had overlooked them all; which took me untill dinner time— Meantime I received two letters from American Captains at Archangel, which determined me to ask a Conference with Count Romanzoff. I answered one of these Letters, to send by the Mail this Night— I walked to the foundery and back; measuring the distances both by time, and the number of paces. Mr: Harris called upon me again this Evening— He had been dining, at M. de Laval’s, and was informed that Baron Blome,
the Danish Minister was taking great pains to obtain the exclusion of American vessels from the Russian Ports— This is most likely, and the reason is obvious enough— He also heard that within the last few days something had occurr’d between the Emperor and Count Romanzoff, which had produced some coolness towards the Count—who by some interference at the army had prevented General Kamensky from making peace with the Turks— He further adds that Mr: Borel told him the Emperor very lately said in a private Audience of Count Romanzoff to the Count— The Emperor Napoleon may do as he pleases— I will not quarrel with the Americans— My occupations of this day disconcerted my regular plan, and gave me grounds for expecting it will be still more discomposed.

7. Visit from Mr: Montréal this morning, and a note from him this Evening— Mr: Roberts went to Cronstadt, to embark for America— He called with Mr: Harris to take leave, while I was out, walking.— Mrs: Adams and Catherine this afternoon went and paid a visit to Mrs: Colombi, in the Country— I wrote to Count Romanzoff, requesting an interview with him; for which he appointed 11. O’Clock to-morrow morning— I wrote to the Secretary of State, respecting the new Manifesto upon the Coins—but the information to give him led me into researches, which employed great part of the day— Without any very urgent business, I never had fewer moments of leisure than I now find.

8. This morning, in the course of a couple of hours, I received by expresses from Cronstadt, successively two large packages; the first, with newspapers, from the Department of State, and letters from Mr: Hellen and the family; enclosed by a Mr: Kettell from Gottenburg— The second with a number of letters and packages from Mr: William Gray; chiefly to his Son, & newspapers from Boston to the 15th: of June— At the same time I had letters from my mother and brother only to the 20th: of February. A Captain Symonds, called upon me from Archangel, upon some private business of his own— So that I was engaged unavoidably untill the instant when by appointment I was to call upon Count Romanzoff— I was even delayed by it as much as a quarter of an hour later than the time he had fixed— On arriving at his house, I found he was gone out, (or otherwise engaged) and was desired to call again in an hour— I went in the mean time to Mr: Raimbert, and requested of him the information for Mr: Kettell, to forward to him by the first mail to Sweden— I returned at the expiration of the hour to Count Romanzoff, whom I now found, and who apologized to me for his absence when I had first called. I immediately began my making to the Count the Representations in behalf of the Americans, who had written from Archangel to obtain my interposition in their favour. The admission of all vessels, direct from the Ports of Portugal in Europe, was prohibited here, by an ordinance of 22. May last.— These vessels sailed from Lisbon, at a time when this Ordinance could not be known there— They have Cargoes, which would sell at very high prices if admitted, and which must in part perish if sent away— I urged as forcibly to the Count as I could that these Circumstances ought equitably to considered as operating to take these vessels out of the purview of the Imperial Ordinance— The Count however, as I expected was inflexible; and gave the obvious answers to my arguments— That the measure was general, and arose from the State of the War— That particular exceptions upon the grounds I had stated could not be admitted— That individual hardships must accrue from every such measure of extensive operation, and that there was no way to prevent them— I then stated the particular circumstances of the “three Sisters,” one of the two vessels, which sprung a leak, and must be repaired before she can go away—suggesting the motives of humanity for granting a permission to sell at least enough of her Cargo to pay for the necessary expences of these repairs— The Count requested me to write to him upon this particular case, which should be taken into consideration— I spoke to him further respecting the affair of Captain Symonds; with which he was already acquainted— He said that as there had been a difference of opinion between the Commission at Archangel, and the Procureur, who was an Officer appointed immediately under the Minister of Justice, two persons had been specially appointed by order of the Emperor to go to Archangel, and to decide upon the business— He took however the attestation from the Commission, which I had received from Captain Symonds, and carried with me, which he promised to examine with due attention— The Count as soon as possible made the conversation general, and with the preliminary caution, which he always takes in inviting me to free Conversation, that he wished me to consider him as laying aside altogether the Chancellor of the Empire, and conversing merely as an individual, he asked
asked me to give him my advice; what was to be done, to restore freedom and security to commerce in the world. I told him with the same reservation that setting aside all official character and responsibility, and speaking merely as an individual speculating upon public affairs, the advice I should give to his Excellency was as soon as possible to convince the French Government, that the Continental System as they called it, and as they managed it was promoting to the utmost extent the views of England; was instead of impairing her Commerce, securing to her that of the whole world, and was pouring into her lap the means of continuing the War, just as long as her Ministers should think it expedient— But I said I could hardly conceive that the Emperor Napoleon was so blind as not to have made this discovery already— Three years experience, with the effects of it becoming every day more flagrant had made the inference too clear and unquestionable. The Emperor Napoleon with all his power, could neither controul the Elements, nor the Passions of Mankind— He had found that his own brother could not, and would not carry his system into Execution, and finally had cast at his feet the crown he had given him, rather than continue to be his instrument there any longer— That Country was now united to France; but the trade with England would be carried on as before, and the only difference would be an increase of contribution to pay some more French Custom-house Officers— The Count partly questioned the accuracy of my Statement, respecting the commercial prosperity of England, but admitted it in the general— He said too that as long as a system was agreed to be pursued, he thought exceptions from it ought not to be allowed— I asked him how that was possible in the present case, when the Emperor Napoleon himself was the first to make such exceptions, and to give licences for a direct trade with England. He said he thought all such licences wrong; and he believed there were not so many of them as was pretended— There was indeed one case here, of a vessel coming both with an English licence, and a licence from the Emperor Napoleon— He was of opinion that she ought to be confiscated for having the English licence— But the French commercial & diplomatic agents were very desirous that she might go free, on account of her French Licence, and perhaps the Emperor in consideration of his ally might so determine— He complained bitterly that all the antient established principles both of commercial and political rectitude had in a manner vanished from the world, and observed with all her iniquities England had yet this advantage over her neighbours of having hitherto most successively resisted all the innovations upon antient principles and Establishments— For his part, since he had been at the head of affairs here, he could sincerely protest that one wish had been at the bottom of all his policy, and the aim of all his labours— And that was universal Peace— The Peace with Sweden had been made— That of Austria had succeeded; but it seemed by some fatality the instant one Peace was made the dearest aim of some people and their indefatigable labour was to make another War— He asked me what I thought would be the effect in England, of this reunion of Holland with France— Some People he said were of opinion that it would produce a great sensation— I said I did not expect so— I believed that the British Ministry, and the thinking men of the Nation would be pretty much of the Duke de Cadore’s opinion, that since the Union of Belgium with France, the system of Holland must necessarily be that of her mighty neighbour, and would feel quite indifferent whether that member of the French Empire, was under the administration of king Louis Napoleon, or under that of the Arch Treasurer Duke of Plaisance— From various other hints, I inferred however that this new arrangement was by no means pleasing to the Count, and of course I presume not to the Emperor. The Count observed also that the king of Prussia had been compelled to shut his Ports against American vessels, which he supposed was a momentary impulse of the Emperor Napoleon to prevent his brother Louis from going to America— I told him I believed it was a measure to which he had been instigated by an English
influence, operating upon his custom house Officers— It was well known that English vessels and English Cargoes, were admitted with the utmost freedom and facility, on payment of a sufficient per centum to the french Officers— As long as American vessels were openly admitted they could not be laid under this contribution— The English traders were thus subject to a disadvantage in the competition of the market; by their instigations the french Officers represented to their Government that the prohibited English trade was carried on under American Colours, and so the king of Prussia is forced to issue an order, excluding American vessels from his Ports— Notwithstanding which I was informed that private letters from merchants gave assurances that they might come as heretofore, and would be admitted on payment of the tax— I added that I hoped we had nothing of the same kind to apprehend here— The Count said that far from it, they should be glad to give every possible facility to the direct Commerce between the United States and this Country; and that he would cheerfully agree to any proper measure to promote its further extension.— But as to the trade with their Enemies, that being forbidden, measures of restriction, necessary to prevent it, must necessarily sometimes occasion inconvenience to real neutrals, and they were obliged to extend the same restrictions to their own subjects— I said that with regard to the imperial ordinances prohibiting trade with England, this was a subject, with which I could have no authority to interfere, and in respect to which I could claim no indulgence. It was the direct trade alone for which I was sollicitous—a trade I flattered myself as useful and advantageous to Russia, as to the United States— I had heard that the Danes irritated perhaps at the loss of their Sound duties, occasioned by the blockade of Elseneur, were endeavouring to obtain the exclusion of our vessels here; and perhaps some representations had been made, by their diplomatic agents here, to that effect— He said he had not heard of any— That if our vessels could escape the pursuit of the Danish privateers, Russia was under no obligation whatsoever to guarantee the payment of Sound duties to the king of Denmark— The right to those duties arose solely from circumstances of locality, and the perception of the duties must be accomplished by Denmark’s own means of execution— At the conclusion of this conference, which lasted about two hours, and in which with the utmost freedom, and earnestness I urged to the Count the total inefficacy of the pretended continental system, to accomplish its professed objects, and the necessity of convincing France that such is the case, I mentioned to him the intention of Mr: Everett and Mr: Gray to visit Moscow, and requested letters for them, which he promised to furnish— He enquired whether Mr: J. S. Smith was yet there, and I informed him that he was gone to the great Fair of Makarief— On returning home, I wrote to Mr: Hellen, in answer to his letter, received this morning, and sent the packet, with the manuscripts concerning the trade of St: Petersburg, and the Accounts furnished by Mr: Raimbert to Mr: Harris, to be forwarded to Mr: Roberts— Mr: Gray, after dinner, sent for his newspapers, and the copy of my lectures which he had received— He had learnt from the Papers, an account of the arrival of Count Pahlen at Philadelphia, which I immediately after dinner, communicated in a note to Count Romanzoff— Mr: Harris came and spent an hour with me this Evening.— Excepting while he was here, I was from dinner time, untill past two in the Morning, absorbed in the perusal of my own lectures, without a conception of the lapse of time; untill at the close of the first volume, upon looking at my watch, I saw with astonishment the hour— What a portion of my life would I give, if they could occasion the same accident to one other human being— But they are now upon their trial in the world— And I pray that I may be duly prepared for resignation to their Fate—whether of total neglect; of malicious persecution—or of deserved condemnation— The first I do not expect— The second is so certain, that my principal difficulty will be in discerning between it and the third, which if it should come, will mortify my Vanity, but even then may have an useful influence upon my heart— By teaching me the lesson of humility.— A lesson which I sorely want, and which I pray God to give me the grace to learn— These lectures are the measure of my powers; moral and intellectual— In the composition of them I spared no labour, and omitted no exertion of which I was capable— I shall never, unless by some special favour of Heaven, accomplish any Work of higher elevation or more extensive compass—

9. The interruption of my systematic occupations, still continues— Letters and packages from America, always engross the first hours, and not infrequently days after their arrival— From the moment of my rising from bed this morning, untill nearly the hour of dinner I was incessantly engaged with Mr: Gray’s newspapers; which coming down to the 13th: of June, contain much news, particularly respecting the new Elections in the State of Massachusetts.— I wrote however an official note to Count Romanzoff, concerning the two American vessels at Archangel, and a private Note requesting letters for Mr: Everett and Mr: Gray at Moscow— I could not walk untill the Evening— On my return home I found Mr: Harris; who spent a couple of hours with us— He has had much conversation with Count Severin Potocki, who is immediately going away— The Count says he does not know what will eventually be done here— The new ordinance respecting the copper coinage gives much dissatisfaction— Count Romanzoff transacts business personally with the Emperor, of which the Council know nothing; the French Ambassador transacts business personally with the Emperor, of which neither the Council, nor Count Romanzoff himself are informed— The universal opinion of all the Council is, at all Events to remain upon good terms with France.

10. This morning I began to resume the first of my regular employments suspended by the packets received from America. But I had morning visits from Mr: Montreal, and from Mr: Glukoff, accompanied by Captain Haskell, of Mr: Gray’s brig Lucia; and a long Evening visit from Mr: Six, whose departure is this day first advertised in the Gazette, and who intends to go in the course of ten days. Mr: Montréal, brought me the paper of information which I had requested for Mr: Kettell at Gothenburg, and which I enclosed in a letter to him and sent, by this day’s Mail.— The French Ambassador, and Mr. Rayneval have in the most solemn manner declared to Mr: Raimbert, that France had used no influence whatsoever in regard to the late confiscations of vessels pretended to have come from Teneriffe— But Mr: Lesseps the Consul has hinted in a conversation at Mr: Severin’s that France had interfered in the case— Captain Haskell, express’d a doubt whether Mr: Gray would be pleased with his Son’s going just at this time to Moscow, in consequence of which I had a long conversation with Mr: Gray after dinner; from which however I saw no reason to conclude that his father would have any objection to this tour. Mr: Six, who is deeply affected with the recent Events in his Country; but who bears up under the misfortune as well as he can, expresses himself much pleased with the measures since adopted by the Emperor of France, as indicating Moderation, and Prudence— He says that his brother Louis is not reconciled with him, and that he must acknowledge that Louis was badly advised, and had fallen into the hands of worthless intriguers— He says also that Jerome and Louis were upon very bad terms with each other— I received from Count Romanzoff a note, respecting the affair of Captain Symonds; and another thanking me for the information of Count Pahlen’s arrival at Philadelphia. Captain Symonds himself was again here this morning, and I told him of the persons gone to Archangel to settle the questions, which have arisen from the differences of opinion between the Commissioners & the Imperial Sollicitor.

11. I had with me this morning an engraver of Seals, who works for the Emperor and Empress, an Artist of the greatest skill, whom I sent to Mr: Harris, to look at his bust of General Washington by Houdon, and see if he could engrave for me from it a head upon a seal, which if he can, I shall have done— I received letters from a Mr: Strong, and a Captain Rich at Archangel, upon business which belonging properly to the Consul, I carried the letters to Mr: Harris, and requested his attention to them, which he promised— I carried to Mr: Lesseps the French Consul a letter addressed to him from the French Consul at Boston, Mr: Giraud, which Captain Haskell brought with him, and gave me yesterday. Mr: Lesseps told me that it informed him that Mr: Giraud had given a certificate of origin to Captain Haskell, of which he would give notice to Count Romanzoff— He said he was glad to receive this letter, because he should in future know Mr: Giraud’s hand-writing; to which he had been unable upon some enquiry not long since to attest.— Walk morning and Evening.
My occupations are still irregular— Yesterday on looking over a National Intelligencer, I found a speech of Mr: Newton, in the House of Representatives in Congress, which makes free use of my Review of Ames’s Works, without any acknowledgment whatsoever— In the Evening I was inclined to compare my quotations from the book, with those read by Mr: Newton, in his Speech, and took up the Review— This led me to read the whole Review again, and imperceptibly again it was past one O’Clock in the morning before I retired to bed.— I rose accordingly this morning between 8 and 9. Wrote but little in the course of the day, and did not retrieve my arrears in this Journal.

12. I resumed this morning the whole of my regular employment before breakfast— And the remainder of the morning was engrossed in retrieving my arrears— Evening walk of about six miles round the Fontanka, and river Quay— Called first upon Mr: Six; but did not find him at home— I read Massillon’s funeral Oration upon Louis 14— It is not equal to the subject— Or rather the subject was of such an equivocal Nature that it was impossible for the Bishop to be truly eloquent about it— The Sermonizing form of a discourse in two parts is constantly observed by Massillon, and as usual he gives very little biography— The glories of Louis’s reign are sufficiently celebrated, though formally announced as Vanity and vexation of Spirit— His misfortunes are acknowledged, but not quite ascribed to their true sources— There are some excellent reflections upon the abuses of national prosperity, and the consequences to which they naturally lead— Louis’s Amorous weaknesses are palliated, but admitted— His too great fondness for War, acknowledged in his own words; but not censured as such a crime in a Christian king ought to have been by a Christian preacher— But although the Bishop faintly blames the massacre of the St Bartholomew, he repeats here the highest approbation of Louis’s persecution of the Protestants, by which France, to the eternal Glory of Louis, was purged of that scandal— This was more than twenty-five years after that persecution commenced— There are at this day few of the most bigotted Catholics who would venture to make that part of Louis’s history a topic of applause.

13. I had visits this morning from Captain Symonds to whom I returned his paper which Count Romanzoff sent me back— From Mr: Fisher, who came with Captain Lewis of Philadelphia, and Mr: Tilden of Boston, and Mr: Plummer, who came with Captain Stanwood, and CaptainCaptain Stanwood brought a packet of letters for Mr: Everett and a bundle of newspapers from Young and Minns, for me. But they were none of them later than the 10th: of April— I neglected to walk before dinner, and the weather confined me to the house the remainder of the day— I read Archenholtz’s Minerva—the Moniteur, and the American Newspapers— These Newspapers consume a great deal too much of my Time

14. The morning was taken up by visitors— Mr: Montréal gave me a minute of the expences of Coinage here at the Mint, and a french Translation of the king of England’s speech, on closing the late Session of Parliament— Mr: J. S. Smith was here, and again an hour or two in the Evening— He arrived in town last Evening; on returning from his tour to Moscow; and to the Fair of Makarief— Mr: Navarro also spent an hour with me, and had some recent political information. I took my customary walk in the Evening— Mr: Hixon wrote me a note informing me than in two or three days he intended to sail for America, and offering to take letters; of which I enclosed to him a packet.

15. I had another visit from Captain Symonds, who told me it was his intention to leave the City this night on his return to Archangel— From Mr: Martin, who enquired concerning the case of Mr: Cutts’s vessel—with regard to which I have no answer from Count Romanzoff; and from Mr: Jewett, who told me that he had been introduced to the Marquis de Traversey, the Minister of Marine, by Mr: Harris; and had been told by him that he would very readily mention to the Emperor, his wish to enter the naval service of Russia; and had no doubt but it would be favourably received by the Emperor; but that it would be necessary for him to have a line of recommendation from me— I told him that I would willingly give him any paper that I could, consistently with my public duty, and which might assist him in the object of his views— I called upon Mr: Six, and Dr: Griffiths, to invite them to dine with us to-morrow— Mr: Six was engaged to dine with the French Ambassador— Dr: Griffiths was not at his lodgings— I dined at the French Ambassador’s at his Hotel in the City; with
a company of upwards of sixty persons, the principal Ministers and Generals of the Country; with the foreign Ministers— It was a great Entertainment in honour of the Emperor Napoleon’s birth day— I spoke to the Marquis de Traversey, about Mr: Jewett— He told me that if I would give him a word of recommendation, the Emperor would take him into his service with the utmost satisfaction— The Minister of the General Police, and Military Governor of the City spoke to me, concerning the black man, whom the Emperor has taken, and for whose wife and children he has promised to send— The Minister had sent me two Officers with messages on the subject; and the man himself who gave me the information necessary for writing to have his family sent here to him— I spoke to M: de Maisonneuve, and to old Count Strogonoff, respecting the Statues in the Count’s Garden, which I had taken for Antiques— Mr: Maisonneuve told me the fine marble one, must from my description of it be a copy of the Remouleur, one of the most famous antiques that was formerly in the Gallery at Florence— That the subject was a slave in the time of the triumvirs, who detected a conspiracy by listening to the discourse of the conspirators, while he appeared to be whetting a knife— Count Strogonoff told me the other, which I had taken for an Egyptian Statue, was an imitation of the Antique Egyptian Sculpture in Granit, done here; and that there was an inscription to that effect upon the Statue— I had a little transient conversation with several others of the Ambassador’s guests— The dinner was in the highest style of Magnificence— Count Romanzoff, and the Grand Marshal Tolstoy as well as the Ambassador appeared in the broad red ribband of the Legion of Honour.— At the Dessert on a signal from Count Romanzoff, the whole Company stood up, and the Count gave the Emperor Napoleon’s health— To which I believe at the same time the Ambassador gave that of the Emperor Alexander— Both however spoke too low to be heard— Drinking Toasts or healths is not customary in this Country, and the Ceremony upon the whole was an aukward one. Count Bussche next to whom I sat at table told me that last Summer at this same entertainment the Ambassador had risen and given the Emperor Alexander’s health expecting that somebody would give Napoleon’s in return, but had been disappointed— But Count Romanzoff was not then here. Mr: Lesseps told me that he had notified to Count Romanzoff, having received from Mr: Giraud the french Consul at Boston letters mentioning that he had given certificates of Origin to Captain Haskell, and another vessel— But he said Mr: Giraud was wrong in giving such Certificates to vessels going any where but to France— Mr: Rayneval told me that he had seen a volume of my lectures at Mr: Six’s, and said they were very handsomely printed— Count Severin Potocki told me he had seen several American pamphlets, among which was a review of Mr: Ames’s works. He said he had never before heard of that Gentleman’s name— Baron Blome took possession of Count Romanzoff immediately after dinner, and kept him seated by his side on a Sopha, untill almost all the company was gone— Prince Galitzin however took his stand before them, and so remained when I left the house. I walked in the Evening on the Quay— The Ambassador’s house was handsomely illuminated.

16. I began yesterday a letter to the Secretary of State to send by Mr: Hixon, and it was with the utmost difficulty that I finished it this day— A Captain Delano came to me this morning with some papers, wanting a certificate that he is a Citizen of the United States— He is Master of one of the vessels which entered at Revel as coming from Teneriffe; and of which the Cargoes have been confiscated— The vessels in general have been discharged— But his register has the name of another Captain upon it; and his name as Captain has not been endorsed upon it. This has occasioned scruples in the Commission, and he has been obliged to come from Revel to St: Petersburg to justify his right to the ship— Mr: Everett and Mr: Gray, being on the point of their departure for Moscow, requested of me a line to the Minister of Police, Balaschoff, asking an order for Post-Horses—which I gave them and they immediately obtained the order— I went with Mrs: Adams to the Plate shops, and procured some necessary articles.
We had company at dinner— Mr: and Mrs: Colombi— Her mother, Baroness Bode, an English Lady, and her Sister— Mr: Navarro, Mr: Harris, Mr: J. S. Smith and Mr: Jewett— Count Rzewuski whom I had invited, but who was engaged, came in after dinner— Walk late in the Evening, to the Marble Palace— The French Ambassador gave this day a second dinner in celebration of his Emperor’s birth-day; to all the French merchants now here.

17. I had this morning a succession of visitors who kept me from Breakfast untill dinner time, almost without an interval. Count Rzewuski, Mr: Six, Mr: Barthe, Mr: Gray, Mr: Boucher, and Captain Symonds— Count Rzewuski and Mr: Six, are on the point of departure; the former for Vienna, and the latter for Paris— Mr: Six told me that his Instructions had been to return to the Empire; but that he had hesitated whether to go directly to Paris untill the Ambassador of his own accord advised him to go— He had then observed that perhaps the Emperor Napoleon might perhaps be displeased at his going there; upon which the Ambassador told him he would give him a letter to the Duke de Cadore; from which Mr: Six concludes that the Ambassador has instructions to send him to Paris. He told me also that he had talked with the Ambassador concerning our affairs— That he could now say with certainty what he had before hinted to me, that probably much of the difficulty of our situation with France, arose from the dislike which our Minister there, had incurr’d of the French Government— That the Ambassador himself would freely converse with me upon the subject if I wished it— That he was persuaded if I was there, the differences between the two Countries would soon be arranged to our satisfaction— He entered into some detail to convince me that I was the only person who could accomplish this, and seemed to expect that I should write all this in substance to the Government of the United States— I told him that I was much obliged to the Ambassador, for his good opinion of me, and that as to himself, as he was going to Paris, if he should find any occasion upon which he could serve our Cause, I should be grateful to him on my own account as well as on that of my Country— That however well I might think of my own qualifications to succeed in making an arrangement between the United States and France, there was too little prospect of the possibility of such success, not to make me very reluctant at the idea of being employed to undertake it; as there was certainly no person in the United States, to whom a failure of such a Negotiation would be personally so injurious as to me— That I had reason besides to suppose that the American Government would prefer keeping me here sometime longer, and sending some other Minister in case General Armstrong should go home. That in the relative situation in which I stood with General Armstrong, I could not in delicacy transmit to the American Government, any general intimation that he was obnoxious to that of France, and that although he had heretofore hinted to me that this was the case, I did not even now know what General Armstrong’s Offence had been— He said they did not impeach his integrity; but that he was morose, and captious, and petulant— Now I am afraid that under the Circumstances in which the General has been there, the last three years, they would have had quite as much reason to be dissatisfied on such grounds with me, as they can have with him— And I am sure I should think it very ill treatment from him, if upon such vague and loose pretences he should transmit to the Government a complaint that I was thought morose, captious or petulant, with suggestions that he himself was the fittest man to take my place— I do not suspect Mr: Six of any ill design in this affair, for I believe him sincerely and cordially my friend, and that of America— Neither do I incline to suspect the Ambassador; I suppose him to be indifferent upon the subject; and rather to have fallen in with Mr: Six’s opinions than to have spoken from any particular Instructions to himself— My own course upon this occasion is plain— To be silent— Mr: Six asked me for another Copy of my letter to Mr: Otis, of which I had already given him one— I gave it him, and also a Copy of the Review of Mr: Ames’s works— He promised me if any thing should occur at Paris, which might be of importance to American Affairs, and which might be useful for me to know, he would directly or indirectly give me information of it— He goes next Tuesday. Captain Symonds was in trouble about his Servant who was stop’d here, just as he was on the point of departure for Archangel— But I could give him no assistance. Mr: Boucher brought me some books on Coins, weights and measures which he lent me— He said he should resume his course of lectures the latter end of next Month; and complained that the Ambassador, with whom he dined yesterday had told him avec un ton qui ne lui convenait peut-être pas, that in his programme for the publication exhibition, there was a gross grammatical error— Mr: Gray came to take leave, and with Mr: Everett left the City this morning for Moscow.— I had only the Evening left, for my daily walk.

18. I had only one visitor this morning, who came before Breakfast—Captain Delano— He was still in some difficulty about procuring his papers— I was at home untill the Evening; wrote a little, and read Newspapers— After dinner, I transiently turned over a volume lent me by Mr: Boucher, on the subject principally of French Coins— I afterwards called upon Mr: Six and had a couple of hours conversation with him— He had been dining this day with Count Romanzoff, and is to dine to-morrow with the Emperor— He leaves this City early in the next week.— This is My Son Charles’s birth day— He is three years old. 2 f. 11 1/2 i.

19. I was unwell yesterday and this day; though not so much as to confine myself to this house— I began again the minutes in writing, on perusal of the New Testament. And finished a letter which I began yesterday to Mr: Gray, at Boston— I read Massillon’s funeral Oration, upon Madame, the mother of Philip Duke of Orleans, Regent of France, during the minority of Louis 15. It is remarkable that this Discourse does not even give the name of the Princess in honour of whom it was delivered; and with regard to her Country, only mentions that she came from Germany— Her name was Charlotte Elisabeth of Bavaria. She was the second wife of Monsieur, only brother of Louis 14. His first wife was Henrietta of England, Sister to Charles 2.— This is the last of the Bishop’s funeral Orations, and they are not in any respect those of his works which do him the most honour— They are all funeral Sermons, and the uniformity of partition, as well as the great sameness in the topics of Eulogy, renders them somewhat tedious— A form of encomium which recurs much too frequently is a very severe general remark upon Princes or Grandees, for the purpose of exempting from that particular censure the person whose panegyric he is pronouncing— Thus he can never tell his auditory that Madame, or Louis le Grand or Monseigneur le Dauphin, were affectionate to their kindred, without adding that kings and Princes in general have no bowels for their family relations— He cannot claim for them the credit of any one virtue, without accusing all persons of their condition, of its opposite vice— This is cheap flattery, and not very severe morality. There is high encomium in this Discourse upon the Regent, Duke of Orleans, who was present to hear it; & who little deserved it. I also read this Evening Robinson’s character of Noah— Evening walk, in a shower— The Nights are rapidly lengthening.

20. Morning visits from Mr: Harris, Mr: Jewett and J. S. Smith.— Mr: Harris desired me to write to Count Romanzoff on the subject of difficulties experienced by American vessels, in obtaining admission, particularly at Archangel— Mr: Jewett has decided upon making a proposal to enter the Russian Service, and came to ask a line from me to the Marquis de Traversey the Minister of Marine, which I wrote and sent him— Mr: Smith brought me a letter from his father, recommending a Mr: Wallace, who has arrived at Archangel— I answered several letters, which I had received from that place— Mr: J. S. Smith dined with us, and after dinner went with the Ladies to Count Strogonoff’s gardens— I only took my Evening walk— I read something in Dubost’s Elements of Commerce, where I find some information; but where all his tables, as far as I know any thing upon the subject are inaccurate; as I have uniformly found them in every such compilation. They also differ from others, in comparative weights and measures of which I know not how to ascertain the true proportions— He gives the Russian pound as equal to 6314. grains Troy weight, differing only two grains from my standard— But his estimates of the Russian Rubles, and his Accounts of the United States Coins, are altogether erroneous— At the close of the Evening I began the perusal of Smith’s Theory of Moral Sentiments— A work that I had not yet read.

21. Visit this morning to Mr: Navarro, who had the news from Sweden, where the brother of the late Crown Prince has been elected, as successor to the throne of Sweden; and from the Army in Turkey, where another victory has been gained by the Russians. I went with the Ladies, and the two Mr: Smith’s to see the Tauridan Palace and its Gardens— It is almost unfurnished, and has nothing about it very remarkable— The Theatre is like that of the Hermitage— The Chapel is small—without seats or benches as the never sit, at the Russian worship, and almost entirely bare— The Servants admitted us to the Sanctuary, but not the Ladies— There are some pictures, chiefly modern and of no great merit— Many Statues and busts, Antique & Modern, Copies and Originals, plaster and marble. Trash and Master-pieces all arranged side by side, for the taste of the Spectator
to distinguish between them— The garden is kept in good order, but has nothing in it very remarkable— There are winding walks, and two iron-bridges over narrow stagnant canals— A variety of trees and flowers; but no running streams— In the House is a Magnificent Hall supported by two rows of Columns, and outside of which is a winter garden from which all the plants at this Season are removed— The building is but of one Story— We were about two hours there, and returned home to dinner— In the Evening, besides my walk to the foundery I read Dubost, and Smith’s Moral Sentiments.

22. There was a Te Deum at Court this day, at Noon, for a splendid victory, though it is said a very dear one gained over the Turks, in the presence of the Grand Vizir, before Shumla— The ceremony was precisely the same, as at the last, for the taking of Silistria. The Emperor, the Empress Mother, the Czarowitz Constantine, and the Grand Duchess Ann were there. I went later than usual, and waited very little— The French Ambassador spoke to me, and said he hoped the differences between his Country and mine would be settled— He assured me, and requested me to write to my Government that it was the desire of the Emperor of France, and of his Ministers to come to the best terms with the United States— That they knew our interests were the same; that he was perfectly persuaded that if any other person than General Armstrong was there, our business might be settled entirely to our satisfaction— I told him that as I was very desirous that we should come to a good understanding, I regretted very much that any thing personal to General Armstrong should be considered by his Government as offensive— I was sure the Government of the U.S. would regret it also, and would wish in learning it, to be informed what were the occasions of displeasure which he had given— “C’est d’abord un très galant homme[”]—said the Ambassador—but he never shews himself—and upon every little occasion, when by a verbal explanation with the Minister, he might obtain any thing, he presents peevish Notes— This is much the same thing as what Mr: Six told me, and appears to me an intriguing manoeuvre, of which I might easily be made the dupe— Just as we were at this stage however of the conversation we were summoned in to the Te Deum— Baron Blome asked me to dine with him to-morrow.— On returning home I found letters from Konigsberg, and was going to Mr: Raimbert’s, when I met Mr: Montréal, who came back with me— Mr: Harris came in soon after— I had much conversation with him on the present State of our affairs here; and on the dangers that threaten them— Mr: Barthe, Mr: Plummer, and Mr: Harris again were here in the Evening— It appears probable that the Horace was taken, under an English Convoy, going from Gothenburg, and carried into Christiansand.

23. I was engaged the whole of this morning in Conversation; first with Mr: Osgood, who called upon me for a Passport; and afterwards with Mr: Harris— I received from Messrs: Meyer & Brüxner a note returning me a part of the charges which they had made against me, by an oversight— Received letters from my family in America, and from Mr: Gray; brought by Captain Groves, who with Captain Coxe arrived yesterday at Cronstadt. I dined with the Baron de Blome in the Country. After dinner he shewed me a letter from Baron Rosenkranz, the new Minister of foreign affairs in Denmark to him, saying that the President Adams and her Cargo, had after due examination been liberated and discharged. And requesting him to communicate this information to me. I then spoke to him, on the subject of the numerous captures of the American vessels, which were under an English convoy, and which have been carried into Christiansand; among which was the Horace.— And desired him to urge to his Government the injustice which there would be in condemning vessels which had been forced into the convoy, and then treacherously deserted by them— Mr: Schoenborn the Swedish Consul told me that the Duke of Augustenburg, brother of the Prince lately deceased, had been unanimously elected as successor to the Crown of Sweden, by the Diet at Oerebro; but it was doubted whether the king of Denmark would permit him to accept the honour— The Company at dinner was small, and I arrived late—found them already at dinner— Walked home in the Evening.

24. Mr: Montréal was here this morning— And while he was with me, Captain Groves, and Captain Coxe came in— They had already been to Mr: Raimbert’s— I called at the house lately occupied by Mr: Six; which has now been taken by Count Schenck the Minister of Würtemberg. His furniture is already partly moved into the house. I went from thence to the shops, and procured some necessary Articles— The letters, and especially the newspapers from America absorb so much of my time, that I have none left for writing— They keep me in a perpetual hurry—. I can now from dinner-time, do scarcely any-thing.

25. I wrote a note this morning to Count Romanzoff, requesting an order to the Custom-House, to have a box, containing some articles for the use of my family, which came from America, delivered to me— Called about noon at Mr: Six’s house, and selected some Articles of his furniture to purchase— Count Schenk, who is moving into the house, was himself there— But not satisfied with the house— The Count is not easily satisfied with any thing.— On returning home from my Evening walk in the Summer Gardens, I found Mr: Harris with the Ladies— He pass’d the Evening with us— All my leisure time for several days has been absorbed by the American Newspapers— Yet there is little in them.

26. My intention is to attend every Sunday, at some one of the places of public worship, and to devote a proper portion of that day to occupations, meditations and studies suitable to it— Yet for several months past I have suffered myself to be diverted from a great part of this purpose—for more than three Months, I have not visited a church, and the devotion of the day has been confined to the perusal of one Sermon of Massillon, and perhaps a few pages of Robinson’s Scripture characters. This day I had destined to some thing more, but scarcely had I risen from breakfast, when a large packet of American Newspapers was brought to me, from Cronstadt—forwarded by Young and Minns— I had not looked them over, when a letter from Archangel, with two dispatches from the Secretary of State, and more newspapers were brought me— The composure and tranquility of mind which my purpose required was now unsettled for this time, and I spent the day, as I have done so many others—upon worldly cares—only reading the first of Massillon’s Sermons on a Religious Profession—that is on a Nun’s taking the veil; and Robinson’s Character of Abraham. The abstraction from temporal passions and affairs, and the attention to religious concerns recommended by both these writers, and equally appropriate to the subjects of their discourses had not sufficient influence upon my mind. Rebel Nature holds out more than half my heart— In the Evening I walked in the Summer Gardens, and on my return home, met Mr: Ashton and Mr: Plummer going from my house— Mr: Ashton goes in two or three days for America, and offered to take letters for me.

27. I sent a Note to Count Romanzoff, requesting a conference with him, and received an Answer, appointing 8 O’Clock to-morrow Evening, for the purpose— Wrote a number of letters, and left a number more unwritten, which I ought to write— Mr: Harris called upon me, and renewed the proposal, which we have so often made and postponed, of going out with the Ladies to visit Madame de Laval, at her Seat, upon Apothecary’s Island.— Mr: Harris accordingly came and dined with us, and after dinner we all went out. We found part of their Monday’s dinner Company still there— Madame de Laval was quite unwell with a severe head-ache. We walked round the Gardens with M. de Laval— After a short visit we returned home— Mr: Harris pass’d part of the Evening with us— Mr: Montréal, and Mr: Martin were part of the Evening with me— I can neither be satisfied with the manner in which I pass my time; nor accomplish a Resolution to employ it better.

28. Mr: Harris was here this forenoon, and again after dinner, with letters from Archangel, and complaints of Masters and Supercargoes of American vessels that they cannot get admitted— Mr: J. S. Smith dined with us— At 8. O’Clock in the Evening I went to Count Romanzoff according to his appointment— I first mentioned to him the despatches which I had received on the subject of Mr: Daschkoff’s application to the Government of the United States in relation to a trade between the United States, and a Russian Settlement on the North-West Coast of America— But I told him I was referred to Documents forwarded by another opportunity, and which I had not yet received.— He said he had also received despatches from Mr: Daschkoff, stating that his application had been favourably received by the Government of the United States— That they had a growing settlement on the North-West Coast of America, and that from it a profitable trade might be carried on to China— That they had sent two vessels there, under the command of Captain Krusenstern, which had gone from there to Canton— Canton was a Port open to all the Nations of Europe; but the Russians who were specially favoured by the Chinese Government had an exclusive trade with them, carried on at a place called Yakta— But the Chinese had refused to admit Captain Krusenstern’s ships at Canton, upon the pretext that as the Russian trade with them had long been carried on with exclusive privileges at Yakta, they supposed that if the Russians meant to change the channel of trade, they would have given them notice of it— And as they had heard nothing about
such vessels coming to Canton, they could not tell, whether they were really Russians or not— There had been the Count said, some Sheets pass’d between the two Governments since on the subject, but the convulsed state of Europe and other objects of so much greater magnitude had so absorbed his attention that they had not yet come to any arrangement with China, for the admission of Russian vessels at Canton— He had therefore wished that the trade from the Russian Settlement on the North-West Coast of America, to China, might be carried on by the Americans— And as the Settlement itself was in the neighbourhood of Indians, who were sometimes troublesome and dangerous neighbours to it, he had thought an arrangement might be concerted with the United States, under which the Americans might have the trade of the settlement, under a restriction not to furnish warlike weapons and instruments to the neighbouring Indians— I told him I collected from the papers which I had received, that Mr: Daschkoff was not specifically instructed, as to the limits within which it was wished that the Restriction should be extended, and asked him whether he could point them out to me— He said that it would require some consideration; but that their maps included the whole of Nootka sound, and down to the mouth of Columbia River, as part of the Russian possessions.— By way of digression the Count explained to me the mode of their Negotiations with China; which is by sending sheets, as they call it; the correspondence is in the name of the Senate; addressed to an Assembly of a like Nature in China; and their sheets are also address’d to the Senate here; who however never see them; and never have any thing to do with the negotiations— At one period of the reign of Catherine 2— The Chinese sent her a sheet to tell her that a Governor of one of the Russian Provinces bordering upon them, was abad man. In consequence of this she ordered an enquiry to be made into his conduct, and found that their complaints were well grounded— The officer was therefore immediately removed, and the Chinese were informed that the Empress had thus proceeded with just attention to their complaints. This compliance however only made them insolent, they sent another sheet, to say that the removal of the offending Governor was not sufficient; but that he must be empaled and his skin sent to them by way of atonement— The Empress was so shock’d at this barbarous and insulting message, that she immediately issued an Edict, prohibiting all her subjects from having any intercourse with the Chinese whatsoever, and this prohibition continued eight or nine years in force— As the trade was a very advantageous one to the Chinese, they became soon very anxious for its restoration, which they solicited during the whole of that time; untill the Empress, like a person who finally becomes weary of resentment consented to the restoration of the trade. Since then, and even now the Chinese practiced a sort of coquetting affectation of indulgence to the Russians— Very lately as I might have seen by the newspapers some of their highest characters, and even a Governor of one of their Provinces had come to a Russian town on the frontiers, and had attended at the celebration of the Mass— It had even given rise to a laughable circumstance. The Chinese Governor, who had heard the whole ceremony performed, standing, was so much delighted with the singing, that he had asked for an instructor, who could teach his son to sing one of those songs— And they had accordingly furnished him a singing Master, who had taught the young man, not the Mass, but some Russian Songs, which he had learnt to sing, very well.— I now recurred to the cases of the American vessels which have arrived at Archangel and at Cronstadt, to whose admission so many difficulties and delays have been opposed— I urged the necessity of a very speedy decision concerning them, stating the certainty that they would be detained for the Winter unless that decision should take place in the course of a very few days—that in every case it would be extremely injurious to the adventurers to be thus detained, and in many cases equivalent to a total loss of the voyage— I urged in particular that the Navigation from Archangel would probably be closed within a month or six weeks— That from the length of the voyages, both in coming and returning of American vessels, made a longer time necessary for them to remain in Port than for others, and pleaded equitably for a peculiar attention of dispatch in their behalf— That after their admission they must yet have time to dispose of the Cargoes they had brought, and to purchase Cargoes for their return; none of which business could be transacted, while they were left in suspense, whether they should be finally admitted at-all. That possibly Baron Campenhausen, whom I had not the honour of being personally acquainted with, and with whom if I did know him, it might perhaps be improper for me to have any conversation upon these subjects, might entertain suspicions in relation to many American vessels, owing to the extraordinary numbers of them which had arrived during the present Season— But the fact was that a number far beyond that of any preceding year had really arrived both here, and at Archangel; coming directly from the United States, and destined to return directly thither— That I had anticipated this
Event, and as he knew, had announced it to him, as infallible, so long ago as last Winter— That the Causes of it were the obstructions to our Commerce, which it experienced in almost every other quarter— The suspension of it by our own Laws in the preceding years; and above all the encouragement which our merchants had derived from the peculiar favour which his Imperial Majesty had been pleased to manifest towards the United States— From my private advices, and from the complexion of the newspapers which I had received down to the middle of June, I knew that the exclusions which we were now subject to, in Prussia, Mecklenburg, and as I expected to learn by to-morrow’s Post, in all the Ports of Holstein, were all expected in America—but many of our Merchants in all the Sea Ports had said, happen to us what will elsewhere, at least we are sure of being well received in Russia.— That I hoped Baron Campenhausen would be made sensible of these Circumstances and of the essential importance to so many of my Countrymen, that they should be immediately admitted— I added that this would be still more urgent for all those who might yet arrive before the close of the Season— That I had received numerous letters, and from a variety of persons, all meeting with the same difficulties; and every one thinking that there were particular Circumstances in his case, which would entitle him to special indulgences and exemptions— I was unwilling to trouble him with each of these cases separately, as I wished them all to participate in the same advantage, and was desirous of sparing him the tediousness of particular details.— That I had already had the honour of addressing to him a note, respecting the vessels which had arrived from Lisbon— That the Supercargo of a vessel arrived at Archangel from New-York, had written to me, to ask whether a special order for his admission could not be obtained on account of his having brought dispatches to me, and also to this Government from Mr: Daschkoff— The Count said this was undoubtedly Evidence that the vessel came from the United States; and he had in other instances alledged it as such himself— But it could not be evidence either of the nature of the Cargo, or that the vessel was not last from some Port of Great-Britain— That it could not be therefore a sufficient foundation for a special order— I then observed that in dwelling so earnestly upon the wish that I had expressed, I flattered myself I was promoting the interests of his Majesty’s Empire, as much as those of my own Country— That the number of American vessels which had come here, and the quantities of the Russian productions which they wanted to take in return, were highly favourable to the agriculture and the manufactures of this Country— That they gave encouragement to its Industry, and contributed more than any thing to support the course of its exchange. Such were the obvious effects of the vessels which had arrived; but I thought it unnecessary to press this argument much, as I was persuaded His Excellency knew better than I did how strongly it was supported by the fact— The Count said he well knew that it was exactly so— That he had been hitherto the Minister of Commerce; but that a new arrangement had been made, by which, all business of this nature was transferred to Baron Campenhausen. That he must do him the justice to say he was an officer of great activity, and dispatched business as fast as he could— But he was extremely apt to entertain suspicions, and possibly some delays might arise from this Circumstance— He the Count was fully sensible of the weight and Justice of the observations I had made to him— He would immediately make a minute of it, in writing, (which he did) and would write to-morrow morning to Baron Campenhausen pressing the subject in a special manner upon his attention— I observed that my Countrymen felt an extraordinary anxiety at these unusual detentions, from remarking their coincidence, with the ordinances of Prussia, Mecklenburg, & Denmark, excluding us from their Ports, and from an apprehension that the same influence under which it was known that those orders had been issued might be exerted even here— He assured me in the most solemn manner
that I might rely upon it there was no foundation for these apprehensions. That the Emperor’s Sentiments and intentions with regard to the United States remained unaltered— But he asked me whether a favourable change had not taken place in the State of our Relations with France— I said that France had partially opened her Ports to the United States. He said he believed there was something still more recent, and that a sort of agreement had been entered into, between France and England, for the allowance of commerce in certain Articles, by means of neutral vessels— I had not heard of this; but I observed that in the midst of all these violent ill offices which France was doing to us, her Government was making the most solemn asseverations of the best possible dispositions, and the most friendly sentiments towards us— That I had within this week or fortnight received such assurances from the French Ambassador here; while at the same time the Mecklenburg and Danish orders for excluding our vessels from all their Ports, were coming out— The French Government too had issued a declarations that the French Consuls in the United States no longer delivered any Certificates of Origin; and therefore that all papers purporting to be of that description, produced by the Masters of American vessels in the Baltic must be forgeries— But nothing could be more false than this assertion— All the vessels coming from the United States, brought certificates of origin given by the French Consuls, and I had myself delivered to Mr Lesseps a letter from the French Consul in Boston, informing him that he had given such a certificate to the Master of the vessel which sailed the latest of any that have yet arrived— In the order to exclude American vessels which they had made the Duke of Mecklenburg sign, that Prince had committed himself to an assertion equally wide from the truth— He affirms that for a long time no colonial articles have been exported from the United States— This was sporting with the common sense of mankind in a manner almost unparalleled— The Count replied that it was indeed extraordinary— And with regard to the Certificates of Origin, he had remarked that the declaration asserted the French Consuls had not delivered any, depuis quelque tems—an expression so vague that it might mean a week or a year, and could warrant no inference to falsify any such papers yet produced— With regard to this system of restriction, the Count seemed to me more than ever convinced of its inefficacy, and prepared at least in his own mind, to give it up— He asked me whether I had heard the news from Sweden— I told him I had heard it rumoured that the Prince of Ponte Corvo, General Bernadotte, was elected Crown-Prince— He said it was true— That there was a Courier coming to him with the account of this Event, who had not yet arrived— But another Courier had— It was a most unaccountable thing in itself, and in the manner of its accomplishment— The Emperor Alexander, had determined that he would in no wise interfere in this election, or manifest his sentiments in an affair so interesting to his neighbours, untill after the conclusion— The Prince of Augustenburg, brother of the late Crown Prince, had in the first instance been unanimously elected; or at most there had been in the secret Committee but one single vote for the Prince of Ponte-Corvo— As the king of Denmark had proposed himself as one of the Candidates, and had written to the king of Sweden, requesting that he would nominate him, the Duke of Augustenburg unwilling to offend his brother in Law, and benefactor, the king of Denmark had not absolutely accepted; but neither had he positively refused. After his Answer the king of Sweden had proposed, and the diet had resolved to renew the offer, and urge the Duke’s acceptance of it— A Courier had been sent to him with this second proposal; but before his answer could be received they had proceeded again to an election, and chosen the Prince of Ponte-Corvo— It was strange enough to see kingdoms given away, by third parties; but to see a nation thus give itself away, was inconceivable— He asked me what I thought would be the sentiment about it in England— I said I believed it would give great displeasure in England, but that it appeared to me the king of Denmark had most reason to be displeased with the issue— I enquired finally of the Count, whether he had any late accounts from the army in Turkey— He said, none since the Te Deum— I complimented him upon the successes of the Campaign hitherto— He said that General Kamenskoy had certainly distinguished himself and given great proofs of military talents— I observed that we Americans were neutrals in this War— And that he knew the fundamental principle of our Policy, was to take no part in the great political affairs of Europe— That by the means of Commerce however we had important relations with them, and that as in discussion with him in my official character, I could speak of nothing but in its relation to Commerce, I must naturally seem to him to attach an importance to subjects of that nature, greater than in his relative estimate they could deserve—
But as he sometimes did me the honour to say that he would lay the Chancellor of the Empire aside, and freely express his sentiments as from one private gentleman to another, I would ask the same indulgence of him in saying that for the commercial interest of my Country, it would be much better that Constantinople should belong to the Emperor of Russia than to the Grand Seignor— He appeared to be much pleased with this remark, and said with a smile that after this War, he hoped the Americans, would have free access to trade with the Russian Possessions upon the Black Sea— This conference lasted more than an hour, when the Danish Minister the Baron de Blome being announced, I took leave of the Count and returned home— Afterwards walked almost to the foundery and came home late in the Evening.

29. I was unable in the course of this day, to get through the account of my Conference with Count Romanzoff; having received successively visits from Mr: Montréal, Mr: Harris, Mr: Navarro, Count Rzewusky and Count Bussche the Westphalian Minister—and letters from Mr: Pitcairn, Mr: George Joy and Messrs: Willink and van Staphorst— Count Rzewusky came to take leave— He is on the point of departure for Vienna the place of his residence— Count Bussche and Mr: Navarro were full of this election of General Bernadotte in Sweden— My letters and the Hamburg Gazette announce the repeal by the Emperor Napoleon of the decrees of Berlin and Milan, and the substitution of prohibitory duties in their stead.— Mr: J. S. Smith spent an hour with us in the Evening— Mr: W. S. Smith has a pamphlet of Remarks upon the Review of Ames’s Works— I read it this Evening—abusive and silly— The review itself, I perceive was used with effect in the last electioneering campaign, in the western part of New-York—

30. I had a long visit this morning from Mr: Harris, and in the Evening one from Count Luxbourg— I just made out this day to finish the account of my conference with Count Romanzoff in this Journal— I have always endeavoured to commit as soon as possible to paper the exact narrative of all important Conferences with Ministers of State; but when business presses hard, this becomes utterly impossible— With the interruptions of visitors which I have had most of which were also upon affairs of business, here are now two days employed in telling a conversation of about an hour— And in the mean time my correspondence runs in arrears.— Mr: Harris says Mr: Borel told him that Count Romanzoff had directed a particular copy to be made of my observations upon the manuscript respecting the armed neutrality— I took this Evening a long walk— The weather has now been very fine and warm for a week— But the thermometer in my chamber never yet above the ordinary Summer heat of Fahrenheit’s scale 77. degres.

31. Visit this morning from Mr Montréal, with whom I had some conversation concerning Mr: Gray’s Affairs and the two vessels, for which they are now purchasing Cargoes.— Baron Campenhausen the Treasurer General of the Empire sent me this Morning a message by His Secretary, with a list of the vessels at Archangel the papers of which have been dispatched— Of those which were ready, and of those which still await the decision of the Emperor— He was directed to tell me that the Baron would use all possible dispatch for the American vessels; that he had reprimanded in the strongest terms the Commission at Archangel, for their delays in transmitting the Papers of American Vessels, and directed them for the future in no case to keep them more than two days. He requested me in case I should in future have any representation of the like nature to make, to apply directly and unofficially to him; which would save the time which must necessarily elapse, by an official application through Count Romanzoff’s Chancery— And as the Post will not go untill next Tuesday to Archangel, offered to send me the Papers now ready, if I preferr’d to send them on by Express— I desired the Secretary to thank Baron Campenhausen, for his obliging attention, and to request him to send me the papers— I immediately called upon Mr: Harris and informed him of these Circumstances— He desired me to send him the Papers as soon as I should receive them— He would send them by the express which Baron Rall would dispatch this Evening for Archangel—as he does every Friday evening.— It was however ten at Night before I received the papers, with a Note from Baron Campenhausen— I sent the papers immediately to Mr: Harris— I found with him a Captain Lovett who informed me he should sail about Monday next for Boston or Salem.— I received yesterday from Count John Potocki, two copies of his new work entitled Principes de Chronologie.

Day. My Mode of life continues regular, as noticed at the close of the two preceding Months— The ardour of pursuit upon weights measures and Coins has necessarily given way to more pressing occupations— My Correspondence has become more active; but my interruptions are still more frequent, and from dinner time, my Evenings are now almost entirely curtailed— Chess has subsided entirely— Cards have become very rare— Music now occasionally takes their place. I have begun to read a little by Candle-light— But it affects my eyes— Russian I am afraid is laid aside, not to be resumed— On the whole Time passes, and leaves no permanent traces behind—
